questions.text: Maternal mortality ratio is expressed in:
questions.correct_answer: B. Maternal deaths per 100000 live births
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Maternal deaths per 100000 live births

Highyeild:

Maternal mortality ratio is the number of maternal deaths per 100000 live births. While calculating maternal mortality rate, the denominator is women of reproductive age group. Birth rate: Number of live births per 1,000 total population. Fertility rate: Number of live births per 1,000 women aged 15–45 years Fetal mortality rate: Number of fetal deaths per 1,000 total births Neonatal mortality rate: Number of neonatal deaths per 1,000 live births Perinatal mortality rate: Number of fetal + neonatal deaths per 1,000 total births Infant mortality rate: Number of infant deaths per 1,000 live births Maternal mortality ratio: Number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false.

Adult JE vaccination : NVBDCP identified 31 high burden districts from Assam, Uttar Pradesh, and West Bengal for adult JE vaccination. Adult vaccination campaign (15–65 years’ age group) with JE was carried out in 21 districts. The remaining 10 districts were covered in the last quarter of 2016–17.

questions.text: The below picture indicates the life cycle of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nipah virus

Highyeild:

The life cycle shows bats and palm tree pots. It also involves livestock like pigs. Transmission of Nipah virus is by direct contact with bats, infected pigs, and from one person to another. Palm sap gets infected by bat excretion which in turn transmits the virus. Nipah virus infection, also known as Nipah virus encephalitis, was first isolated and described in 1999. The name Nipah is derived from the village in Malaysia where the person from whom the virus was first isolated succumbed to the disease. Reservoir: – Zoonotic disease – Large fruit bats (flying foxes) are the natural reservoirs of Nipah virus Mode of transmission – Pig to human – Bat to human – Human to human Consumption of bat bitten fruits Pigs—amplifying hosts and intermediate host Incubation period: 5–18 days Symptoms: – 3–14 days of fever and headache followed by drowsiness, disorientation, and mental confusion. These signs and symptoms can progress to comma within 24–48 hours – Respiratory illness is also seen during the early phase of infection Diagnosis: – Early stage : RTPCR – Later stage : Antibody ELISA (IgG and IgM) – Autopsy : IHC (Immunohistochemistry) Prevention: – No specific treatment available – Ribavirin has been shown to be effective

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and D are false.

questions.text: Pick the right answer when 2 screening tests are done in series:
questions.correct_answer: B. Increased specificity and decreased sensitivity
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased specificity and decreased sensitivity This is a case of tests in series. If two screening tests are done one after another (only after one test becomes positive), it is known as series testing and when two tests are done simultaneously to look for any positive test it is known as parallel testing.

Highyeild:

Testing strategy Parallel testing Serial testing Procedure Two screening tests performed at the same time and the results are subsequently combined Second screening test is performed only if the result of the first screening test is positive Effect Higher sensitivity but lower specificity Improves specificity at the cost of lower sensitivity Sensitivity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease (cases). Specificity: Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease (healthy). Positive predictive valve (PPV) : Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who have the disease, out of all those who test positive on a screening test. Negative predictive valve (NPV) : Ability of a screening test to identify correctly all those who do not have the disease, out of all those who test negative on a screening test. If multiple tests are applied in series, the specificity of the complete testing increases.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, C and D are false.

questions.text: In a clinical trial, blood pressure was measured in a group of patients before and after treatment, which of the following tests will be suitable as a test of significance:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Paired t-test

Highyeild:

Unpaired t - test (aka Student’s test ) compares two different subjects. The paired t - test reduces intersubject variability (because it makes comparisons between the same subject), and thus is theoretically more powerful than the unpaired t - test .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. The Mann–Whitney U test (also called the Mann–Whitney–Wilcoxon (MWW/MWU), Wilcoxon rank-sum test, or Wilcoxon–Mann–Whitney test) is a nonparametric test of the null hypothesis that, for randomly selected values X and Y from two populations, the probability of X being greater than Y is equal to the probability of Y being greater than X. Option C. A t-test is any statistical hypothesis test in which the test statistic follows a Student's t-distribution under the null hypothesis. It is most commonly applied when the test statistic would follow a normal distribution if the value of a scaling term in the test statistic were known (typically, the scaling term is unknown and therefore a nuisance parameter). Option D. ANOVA is to test for differences among the means of the population by examining the amount of variation within each sample, relative to the amount of variation between the samples. Analyzing variance tests the hypothesis that the means of two or more populations are equal.

questions.text: Following blood transfusion, blood bags are disposed in which color coded bin?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Yellow

Highyeild:

Red category waste is contaminated recyclable waste containing primarily plastics generated from disposable items such as tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers, and gloves. This includes waste pipette tips, plastic pipette, Eppendorf, rubber teats, drains, oxygen mask, thick plastic splash proof gowns, rubber apron, ICT test cards, ELISA plate, and vials not containing blood samples. Types of waste : Yellow (c) - Soiled Waste Segregation: Items contaminated with blood/body fluids like dressings, plaster casts, cotton swabs and bags containing residual or discarded blood and blood components. This includes used infectious materials such as caps, shoe-cover, blotting paper/gauze, wooden swab stick, paraffin blocks, indicators tapes, and disposable (single use non-linen based) masks and gowns.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and D are false.

Extraedge:

New Biomedical Waste Management Guidelines: Ministry: Ministry of Environment and Forest. Legislation: Sections 6, 8, and 25 of Environment Protection Act, 1986. These rules shall not apply to radioactive wastes, hazardous chemical, municipal solid wastes, lead acid batteries, hazardous wastes, e-waste, hazardous microorganisms, genetically engineering microorganisms.

questions.text: A known case of TB is now resistant to Rifampicin and Isoniazid. Which of the following would be most appropriate in treating this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: 6 drugs for 4 months; 4 drugs for 12 months

options.label: B
options.text: 4 drugs for 4 months. 6 drugs for 12 months

options.label: C
options.text: 6 drugs for 6 months; 4 drugs for 18 months

options.label: D
options.text: 5 drugs for 2 months; 4 drugs for 1 month; 3 drugs for 5 months

questions.correct_answer: C. 6 drugs for 6 months; 4 drugs for 18 months
questions.explanation:
Solution:

6 drugs for 6 months; 4 drugs for 18 months

Highyeild:

Resistance to rifampicin and isoniazid is termed as multiple-drug-resistant TB (MDR-TB). In such a case, 6 drugs are used for 6–9 months in an intensive phase followed by 4 drugs for 18 months in a continuous phase. The number of drugs used for specific duration in a particular type of TB is given below: Non-drug resistant New case 4 drugs for 2 months + 3 drugs for 4 months Non-drug resistant : Previously treated 5 drugs for 2 months + 4 drugs for 1 month + 3 drugs for 5 months Rifampicin resistance + Isoniazid sensitive 7 drugs for 6–9 months + 5 drugs for 18 months MDR-TB: 6 drugs for 6–9 months + 4 drugs for 18 months XDR-TB: 7 drugs for 6–12 months + 6 drugs for 18 months

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and C are false.

questions.text: Dose of levonorgestrel used for emergency contraception:
questions.correct_answer: A. 1.5 mg in 2 doses within 72 hours
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1.5 mg in 2 doses within 72 hours

Highyeild:

Dose of levonorgestrel in emergency set up is 75 mg tablet within 72 hrs of unprotected sex and next dose of 0.75 mg after 12 hrs of the 1 st dose. Two regimens are available. Plan B (Progesterone only pills) is considered to be the current regimen of choice. It has to be taken within 72 hours. Copper-containing IUDs are the gold standard (100% effective) and can be taken up to 120 hours. Mifepristone single dose is also an alternative for up to 120 hours.

questions.text: All of the following related with the following image are right except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Negatively skewed

Highyeild:

This is called Box and Whisker plot. It was introduced by Tukey in 1970. It is a graphical representation of numerical data based on five-figure summary—minimum, 25th percentile, median (50th percentile), 75th percentile, and maximum values. The whisker represents the range of the data, while the box represents the interquartile range; i.e., from 25% to 75% of values (first to third quartile) the median or second quartile is represented by a partition in the box.

Duration of isolation for different infectious disease Disease Duration of isolation Pertussis 4 weeks or until paroxysms cease Chicken Pox Until all lesions crusted, usually about 6 days after the onset of rash Measles From the onset of catarrhal stage through the 3rd day of the rash German measles None, except that women in the first trimester or sexually active, non-immune women in child-bearing stage and not using contraceptive measures should not be exposed Cholera 3 days after tetracycline started, until 48 hrs of antibiotics (or negative cultures after treatment) Shigellosis and Salmonellosis Until 3 consecutive negative stool cultures Hepatitis A 3 weeks Influenza 3 days after rash Polio 2 weeks – adult, 6 weeks – pediatric TB (sputum+) Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy Herpes Zoster 6 days after the onset of rash Mumps Until swelling subsides Meningococcal meningitis Until the first 6 hours of effective antibiotic therapy are completed Streptococcal pharyngitis Until the first 6 hours of effective antibiotic therapy are completed

questions.text: In a clinical trial, blood pressure was measured between two independent groups following treatment, which of the following test will be suitable as a test of significance?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Unpaired t-test

Highyeild:

Test Use Paired t-test Comparing means in paired data (in the same group of individuals before and after an intervention) Unpaired t-test Comparing means in two different group of individuals Z-test It is a variant of t-test which is used when sample size is >30 Chi-Square test Comparing percentage, proportions, and fractions in two or more different group of individuals ANOVA Comparison of several groups (three or more)

questions.text: The test used to identify frozen vaccine is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Shake test

Highyeild:

Shake test is used to check if freeze-sensitive vaccines (e.g., Pentavalent, PCV-10, TT, or Hep. B have been subjected to freezing temperature likely to damage them. Steps: Prepare a frozen control vial (same type, batch number, and manufacturer as the vaccine to be tested) and freeze for at least 10 hours at –10°C and then let it thaw. Choose the suspected frozen test vial. Shake the control and test vials vigorously for 10–15 seconds. Allow the vials to rest on table side by side. If the vaccine in the suspected test vial shows a much slower sedimentation rate than the vaccine in the frozen control vial, we conclude that the test vaccine has most probably not been frozen and can be used.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options B, C and D are false.

questions.text: A healthy center reports 40 to 50 cases in a week in the community. This week there are 48 cases normally. This is called:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endemic

Highyeild:

Endemic Constant presence of a disease or infectious agent in a defined geographical area. It is the usual or expected frequency of a disease in a population. Epidemic Single exposure or point source epidemics: All cases develop within one incubation period. Continuous or repeated exposure epidemics: Secondary waves or peaks. Propagated epidemics: Results from person-to-person transmission. Sporadic Cases which are “scattered about” Cases that are widely separated in space and time. There is no recognizable source of infection.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options A, B and D are false.
